Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Innovative Advection-Enhanced Geothermal Heat Pump Fieldloop Demonstration
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to address the high costs associated with building heating and cooling in a sustainable fashion. Heating/cooling constitute approximately 48% of building energy consumption. Ground-source or geothermal heat pumps (GSHPs) represent an energy-efficient and environmentally sustainable heating and cooling solution, but their high upfront capital costs have significantly limited deployment. This project takes a fundamentally different approach to GSHP heat transfer, with the expected result that installation costs are decreased by up to 50% and operating costs by 20% compared to conventional GSHP systems. This project will thoroughly field test and analyze the performance of the GSHP innovation, advancing the technology design and installation parameters, and readying it for commercial deployment.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the problem of the high installation cost and large, disruptive footprint of GSHP systems, with the objective to provide a cost-effective, widely-deployable, renewable solution for building heating and cooling. This project will advance an innovative GSHP field loop technology from numerical and laboratory analyses to manufacturing and field testing. The overall research objective is to determine the performance of the innovative GSHP field loop under real-world conditions. The research program includes: 1) development of a comprehensive numerical model of the innovative GSHP system for field sites; 2) field testing, including final design, installation, and operation of equipment at a field site; 3) numerical model and equipment design refinement following initial field testing; 4) installation and testing of modified equipment; and 5) development of a comprehensive cost, energy use and emissions model. It is anticipated that the project will result in a commercially-ready GSHP product, with design and installation guidelines, that substantially (by up to 50%) reduces the installation cost of GSHPs while improving their performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed a novel approach to cut by up to half the upfront installation cost and improve the coefficient of performance (COP) of the most energy efficient and environmentally friendly heating and cooling technology, groundsource heat pumps (GSHP). Our innovation is an advective GSHP (AGHP) that fundamentally changes the approach to subsurface heat exchange in GSHP systems. Rather than relying entirely on heat conduction, the AGHP also utilizes advection and convection properties of heat exchange. It explicitly considers and fully uses the thermal exchange properties of water, including advective and convective energy transfer, the additional heat capacity that water provides relative to earth and sediment, and the diffusion mechanism/transport medium for traditional GSHPs.

In this SBIR Phase I research effort, we sought to answer the following technical questions:

  • Whether the combination of the proposed wellbore design and heat exchanger design can deliver the anticipated amount of heat exchange capacity, and that these designs are sufficiently optimized for future commercialization.
  • Whether groundwater flow can be sufficiently induced to provide the desired level of heat exchange, and that the appropriate mechanism is utilized.
  • Whether individual wellbores can perform in a sufficiently independent fashion so as not to impact the performance of nearby or adjacent wells in the same aquifer. This question was to be addressed in one of two ways: 1) if the first AGHP well installed in the field performed as designed, then a second well would be installed near the first to field-test both wells simultaneously, or 2) if the first well required significant upgrades to meet desired performance, then this effort would be completed numerically.

To answer these questions, we completed a series of tasks, described below, that included analytical and numerical modeling of our heat exchanger system and hydrogeologic numerical modeling, design/development and manufacture of equipment, and extensive testing in the field.  Installation and testing of the AGHP system in the field was the critical component of the present effort.  We encountered several challenges throughout the process that led to numerous design and construction improvements.

In addition to these technical advances to our system, we also made iterative improvements to our testing methodology and progressively bolstered our own understanding of how the system operates, using this data to update our numerical models of the heat exchanger and of the hydrogeology.

Through the course of Phase I, we tested three heat exchanger designs (one more than originally anticipated in our SBIR Phase I application) in two different wells.  We also had the opportunity to test  two distinct types of geological formation, one more than originally anticipated. Using an analytical approach, we designed the second- and third-generation heat exchangers (heat exchanger 2 and 3). The performance of these designs was then analyzed with numerical simulation, which was also used to strengthen the analytical models. After the completion of our January 2021 testing, we have shown that the heat exchanger performs within 5-10% of the analytical models, both demonstrating AGHP performance and providing a modeling platform for efficient system analysis going forward.

Finally, and most significantly, we have shown that heat transfer in the AGHP system is driven by advection, the real heart of our technology, and can indeed provide an order of magnitude more heat transfer per well than a traditional GSHP borehole. The associated field loop installation cost savings and operating cost improvements compared to traditional GSHP?s are sufficient to improve the system?s simple payback versus conventional natural gas-based HVAC systems, to less than 5-7 years on average, vs. traditional GSHP paybacks of 15-20+ years. The AGHP payback surpasses a critical viability threshold for the average building developer or owner. Although additional testing and work lies ahead of us, our continued learnings through each round of development and testing, and the associated improvements in system performance have us well-positioned for commercial success.
